title: The Pragmatic Programmer
author: David Thomas & Andrew Hunt
description: Your journey to mastery. A guide for software craftsmanship covering best practices, tips, and philosophies.
review: A timeless classic that every developer should read. Practical and actionable advice throughout.

title: Clean Code
author: Robert C. Martin
description: A handbook of agile software craftsmanship for writing readable, maintainable, and elegant code.

title: Designing Data-Intensive Applications
author: Martin Kleppmann
description: The big ideas behind reliable, scalable, and maintainable distributed systems.
review: Incredibly comprehensive. Makes complex concepts accessible and practical.

title: The Phoenix Project
author: Gene Kim, Kevin Behr & George Spafford
description: A novel about IT, DevOps, and helping your business win through improved flow and feedback.
summary: Illustrates DevOps principles through a compelling narrative about saving a failing IT project.

title: Deep Work
author: Cal Newport
description: Rules for focused success in a distracted world. The power of distraction-free concentration.
review: Changed how I approach my work day. Incredibly effective strategies for focus.

title: Atomic Habits
author: James Clear
description: Build good habits and break bad ones through tiny changes that deliver remarkable results.
review: Practical and immediately applicable. The 1% improvement framework is powerful.

title: Eloquent JavaScript
author: Marijn Haverbeke
description: A modern introduction to programming with JavaScript, covering fundamentals and advanced topics.

title: You Don't Know JS
author: Kyle Simpson
description: Deep dive into the core mechanisms of JavaScript, exploring scope, closures, and the object system.
summary: Goes beyond basic syntax to explain how JavaScript really works under the hood.

title: Refactoring
author: Martin Fowler
description: Improving the design of existing code through systematic techniques for restructuring.
review: Essential reading for maintaining large codebases. The catalog of refactorings is invaluable.

title: Domain-Driven Design
author: Eric Evans
description: Tackling complexity in the heart of software through strategic design and ubiquitous language.

title: The Mythical Man-Month
author: Frederick Brooks
description: Essays on software engineering and project management, exploring why adding people to late projects makes them later.
summary: Classic insights on software project management that remain relevant decades later.

title: Code Complete
author: Steve McConnell
description: A practical handbook of software construction covering design, coding, debugging, and testing.

title: Thinking, Fast and Slow
author: Daniel Kahneman
description: Explores the two systems that drive thinking: fast, intuitive System 1 and slow, deliberate System 2.
review: Fascinating insights into how we make decisions and the biases that affect our judgment.

title: Sapiens
author: Yuval Noah Harari
description: A brief history of humankind, from the Stone Age to the modern age of artificial intelligence.
summary: Explores how Homo sapiens came to dominate the world through cognitive, agricultural, and scientific revolutions.

title: Educated
author: Tara Westover
description: A memoir about growing up in rural Idaho and the transformative power of education.
review: Powerful and moving. A testament to resilience and the pursuit of knowledge.

title: The Design of Everyday Things
author: Don Norman
description: How to create products that are easy to use, understand, and enjoy through good design principles.

title: Don't Make Me Think
author: Steve Krug
description: A common sense approach to web usability, making websites more intuitive and user-friendly.
summary: Practical advice on creating websites that are obvious, self-evident, and self-explanatory.

title: Getting Things Done
author: David Allen
description: The art of stress-free productivity through capturing, organizing, and reviewing tasks.
review: Revolutionary approach to personal productivity. The weekly review is a game-changer.

title: The Lean Startup
author: Eric Ries
description: How to use continuous innovation to create radically successful businesses through validated learning.

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
description: Personal writings of the Roman Emperor on Stoic philosophy and self-improvement.
review: Timeless wisdom on virtue, resilience, and living a meaningful life. Returns dividends with each reading.

title: Man's Search for Meaning
author: Viktor Frankl
description: A psychiatrist's account of surviving Nazi concentration camps and finding meaning in suffering.
summary: Argues that we can find meaning in life even in the most brutal circumstances.

title: The Art of War
author: Sun Tzu
description: Ancient Chinese military treatise on strategy, tactics, and leadership applicable beyond warfare.

title: How to Win Friends and Influence People
author: Dale Carnegie
description: Timeless principles for building relationships, winning people over, and becoming more influential.
review: Surprisingly relevant today. The emphasis on genuine interest and empathy is powerful.

title: Essentialism
author: Greg McKeown
description: The disciplined pursuit of less but better, focusing on what truly matters.
summary: Makes the case for doing fewer things but doing them exceptionally well.

title: Start with Why
author: Simon Sinek
description: How great leaders inspire action by starting with purpose before explaining how or what.

title: The 4-Hour Workweek
author: Timothy Ferriss
description: Escape the 9-5, live anywhere, and join the new rich through automation and lifestyle design.
review: Provocative ideas about work, productivity, and lifestyle. Not all advice applies universally but worth reading.

title: Creativity, Inc.
author: Ed Catmull
description: Insights on building a creative culture from the co-founder of Pixar Animation Studios.
summary: Explores how Pixar fosters creativity while maintaining commercial success in animation.

title: Zero to One
author: Peter Thiel
description: Notes on startups and how to build the future by creating something truly new.
review: Contrarian and thought-provoking views on innovation and building valuable companies.
